newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGBs end easier on firm stocks despite strong yen.
newsitem.headline: JGBs end easier on firm stocks despite strong yen.

text.p: Key June 10-year Japanese government bond (JGB) futures closed easier on Monday, weighed down by firmer Tokyo stock prices, despite the yen's strength against the dollar.

"There were expectations earlier that a strong yen was a buy sign for JGBs, as it would hurt Tokyo stock prices. But stocks were not negatively impacted, which was a disappointment for JGBs," said a dealer at a "Big Four" brokerage house.
"That was the exact market reaction, monetary authorities had hoped for," he said. The June posted a third day of losses and ended Monday down 0.06 at 123.39.
The contract rose as high as 123.99 soon after the opening.
Its session low was 123.21. Turnover was 59,222 contracts.

In afternoon trade, comments from Taku Yamasaki, chairman of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's policy research council, that a rise in Japan's interest rates would undermine the economy, provided brief support. But the rally was short-lived as the comments were seen as aimed at curbing the yen, rather than checking higher interest rates, traders said.
"The market reacted to Yamasaki's first comment. But later we realised his comments were aimed at curbing the yen's rise as he did not rule out a rate hike," a bank dealer said.

Speaking at the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan, Yamasaki said: "If the level of interest rates is raised, it may increase consumption by individuals who receive interest income, but overall, I think it is reasonable to think that it (raising rates) would have a negative effect on the economy."
"If the economy's recovery becomes full-fledged, raising interest rates will become possible," he said.
He said that in addition to fiscal and monetary policies, the economy can also be stimulated through tax policies.
The dollar was quoted at 118.72/82 yen at 0655 GMT, after falling as low as 117.50 yen in morning Tokyo trade.
It ended Friday's New York session at 120.20/30 yen.
"The strong yen would help Japan reduce its huge trade imbalance but its negative effect on stocks had been a headache for authorities," the first dealer said.
The Nikkei 225 average gained 340.73 points or 1.72 percent to close at 20,143.51. It hit a morning low of 19,560.06.
A strong stock market would give the Bank of Japan greater flexibility in setting its monetary policy, traders said.
They said authorities were not worried about higher bond yields as banks would profit from the wider spread between interbank market rates and higher lending rates.
The Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd is scheduled to announce its long-term prime rate for May later on Monday.
Bankers said the prime rate was expected to be raised to 3.1 percent in May from April's record-low 2.5 percent.

Some traders said public funds may reduce JGB buying and increase lending as a result of the higher prime rate, which will push public-fund lending rates below those of private banks for the first time since May 1996.
The government's long-term lending rate has been at 2.6 percent since May 9.
-- Risa Maeda, Tokyo Treasury Desk +81-33432-8570
